citation.article-title: Characteristics of a new obligate methylotroph.

p.s: Description of Methylobacillus flagellatus sp. nov.
Methylobacillus flagellatus (Fla.gel.la.tum: from Latin flagellum; flagelatum from Latin for attached flagellum, flagellated)
Cells are mobile gram-negative bacilli (1.4-1.8) x (0.5-0.6) μm in size, reproduce by division, do not form spores or capsules.
Colonies on agarized medium with methanol are round, translucent, with milky color, and surface is smooth, the profile convex. the edge even, structure is finely granular, consistency is viscous.
It is an obligate methylotroph: it utilizes only methanol and methylamine as the source of carbon and energy.
It consumes methylamine, ammonia salts, dimethylamine, nitrates, and peptone as the source of nitrogen.
It grows in a temperature range of 10-25°C and a pH of 5.8-8.4.
Optimal values are 42°C for temperature and 7.2-7.3 for pH.
Generation time is 2h.
It does not require vitamins.
It does not form acids or gases from glucose.
It does not peptonize milk.
The arginine test is negative.
Tests for urease, catalase, and oxidase are positive.
It hydrolyzes starch but not cellulose, gelatin, or Tween-80.
It reduces nitrates to nitrites.
It employs the BMP pathway of assimilation of formaldehyde (Entner-Doudoroff variant).
It assimilates ammonia by reduction amination of α-ketoglutarate by glutamate dehydrogenase.
Predominant acids in the fatty acid composition of cells are C16:0 and C16:1.
The ratio of cis-vaccenic to palmitoleic is 0.32.
Content of DNA GC is 55.5 mole %.
Level of DNA-DNA to M. glycogenes ATCC 29475 is 18%, more than 30% for P. thiaminophague ATCC 21371, and P. insueta ATCC 21276.
The type species of M. flagellatum KT was isolated from sewage and is stored in the collection of the Institute of Biochemistry and Physiology of Microorganisms, Academy of Sciences of the USSR.
